Absolutely the best and biggest Gyro, I've ever had. I've ordered their Stuffed Gyro Platter and their regular Gyro, both were awesome! If you have a picky kid, leave them at home, they refuse to leave out an ingredient or substitute an ingredient. Service is hit or miss. They always seem to be packed and under-staffed. One server for like the entire place?? It's insane. They don't use salt, why I don't know, so some things come out bland, like their deep fried spinach appetizer ball (don't know the actual name). But then other appetizers are so good, we fight over them.

Menu has a lot of variety and servings are good size. It can be pricey though. I'll go back, but not during busy lunch or dinner hours.

I love Romeo's!!! I've been going to his restaurants for over 20 years and have never been disappointed. Whether it's a romantic dinner or a casual lunch, he never disappoints. I had a business lunch appointment there last week and had the Corinthian Salad. I had plenty of left overs for lunch the next day and what was so impressive to me was the perfect amount and combination of ingredients to last to the very last bite! Usually you have a plateful of lettuce but I was happily noshing feta, mushrooms, roasted peppers, olives, artichoke hearts and capers.  Ummm, now I'm hungry!!!

I went out with my family in downtown Gilbert in search of a place we never tried before. This place popped up so we decided to give it a try.

It's inside a little shopping plaza and seems small until you walk inside. The front area has a little shop and and a giant dessert case!!

We finally sat down and looked at the menus. If you love a lot of choices, this is the place for you. They have a lot of Greek foods and other foods as well.

I got the baked feta as an appetizer which had bell peppers, garlic, olive oil, olives and onions on top. It was absolutely fantastic! Definitely worth a try. I also got the tortellini with crab and white wine sauce. This dish was a prefect mix of the cream and crab together. It also came with a side of soup which was scrumptious. The pieces of beef int he soup were delectable. 

The prices were a little high but all the food was great quality. I would have given this place more stars but the service was extremely slow. Luckily we had nowhere to be but if you were in a rush, this is not the place to go. It's more of a place you can relax and share stories for hours.

So go try some Greek cuisine!

I have been here many times....love the food and the variety is awesome.  If you want freshly made entrees go here...I really enjoy the peppers spanaki  and the dill fritters...the desserts are also amazing.  The owners definitely know their business!

I HAVE BEEN GOING TO EURO CAFE FOR OVER 15YRS but after today I will never return!  I have never been treated soooo rudely in my entire life! The waitress was GREAT- it was Mr. Romeo himself.  I was invited by a family member to lunch along with my mother.  Mr Romeo participates in program for business which gives vouchers for trade. On these vouchers in states DINE IN ONLY.  My siser was given these vouchers as a bonus from work. We used the value of the vouchers plus we purchased dessert. When it was time to pay the waitress informed us that we can only use these for TAKE OUT-We showed her that it says DINE IN ONLY-so she went to get permission. THIS IS WHERE IT GETS GOOD! Mr Romeo is by no means a little man-so when he enters a room people look. He walks to our table that is surrounded by other guests and says "LETS NOT DO THIS AGAIN!"   "Next time its for take out only, When i'm not here some waitresses may allow this but when it comes to fri night-I need the money!"  "I can't keep doing this,,so please help me ou here!"  We sat there like 3 little kids that just got scolded for stealing!! Everyone was watching and listening-we were mortified!  It's Simple MR. ROMEO-IFYOU DO NOT WANT TO PARTICIPATE IN THIS PROGRAM THEN GET OUT-DO NOT HUMILATE YOUR GUESTS.  I WILL BE LETTING A LOT OF PEOPLE KNOW HOW WE WERE TREATED. FYI-You could have handled this in such a better way!

I've been here a couple of times and have always loved the food. The first time I ordered the Corsican sub which was delicious (think French bread+meat sauce+ sausage+pepperoni+ cheese) what's not to like? The food came out fast, was hot and the portions were large. The waiter was wonderful and very attentive. We ended dinner with a slice of cake called the cafe euro cake(?) or something like that. It was basically a chocolate Kahlua cake and was amazing! 

The second time I came here just for the desserts. They have a beautiful dessert counter with an array of delectable sweets from truffles to cookies to pies to tarts and cakes with rather interesting names (satin bondage anyone?). We ordered a couple of different desserts (few different slices of cake, espresso truffles, chocolate chip cookies and a pecan pie bar). The truffles, cake and cookies were excellent but the pecan pie bar was clawingly sweet and tasted sort of freezer burned, which was a bit of a let down. Still love their food and would definitely come back!

An interesting place theme-wise - quaint, crowded. As the name suggests, european in both look and feel. A bit fussy somehow. Huge menu. I really liked the pasta salad I ordered - huge portion as previously mentioned. However afterwards I couldn't help thinking, damn, I could do this myself at home! 

It inspired me to explore vinagrettes in general and eat more vegetables which is a good thing. And I was right about being able to make the dressings. BTW, walmart has this new thing called a multi-mixer which is great for making (and storing) your own vinagrettes at home. Check out epicurious. But I digress. 

To wrap up, huge menu, ok to good food, mostly high prices especially on dessert items. I took home the peanut butter cheesecake but was not impressed with it. Plus it was about $6 a slice. The case definitely beckons but I wouldn't fall to temptation there again.

Also notably, the wait staff was slow, unresponsive and not particularly friendly even though there was only one other couple in the whole restaurant. Maybe they've been told to be that way in line with the European theme??? just kidding but it does make one wonder...

After all of these years- still amazing! I've been ordering the tortellini feta salad for years and it still does not disappoint. Gyro platter is fantastic. The best part is their dessert case. Recommend the Dangerous Dilemma and The Morning After. Great names, fabulous taste. Made from scratch and truly delicious. Excellent selection of wines. Perfect for date night.
Nice atmosphere and delicious treats!  Comfortable seating....classy.  Met with a new neighbor there.  Gilbert is so real.

We haven't been back in a long time and decided to give it another try. I had the Dacia pocket sub and it was delicious! My wife had the seafood pasta with shrimp and calamari. It was ok. Not worth $18 but decent. We had the peanut butter brownie and cherry whiskey chocolate cake for dessert. Both were amazing! So moist and rich. Service was friendly but drinks were way overpriced! $8 for a well gin/tonic! $7 for a well vodka/soda. End of story, great menu, lots of great choices, Just drink elsewhere first. Everything on Gilbert road is packed and this place was dead... granted they face they back alley but I think they need to revive the place with better pricing and happy hour. Their HH ends at 5pm. Just my suggestion.

Was there last night for the first time. Thankfully we got there early, since they were very understaffed. The waiter did a good job, dispite the fact that he was dealing with around 10 tables. The menu is vast. When my wife asked for a slight change (having mushrooms omitted from her dish) it seemd like a major deal. The waiter said, "The Chef dosen't like to make changes to his cooking"....Are you kidding me? How hard is it not to add mushrooms?. After asking the Chef, he agreed to our request. I read other reviews that had the same complaint. They need to be more accommodating!!!! The food was "OK"......but wasn't "5" star by any means. Not likely to return to this place.

I was very excited to try this place after reading all the positive reviews and also seeing their extensive menu. Upon arriving, we were surprised to see just how small this place was (the pictures make it look bigger) and also surprised to see several leaks from the ceiling. Many tables were not available to be used because there were giant buckets at or near them catching water that fell from the ceiling (we had a storm a day before). Kind of off putting but we decided to stay and give it a try anyway. The husband decided to have a gyro since his logic told him that a euro cafe should have the best gyros. The waitress assured him that it would be the best gyro he has ever had. I opted for the pork molise which was pork tenderloin wrapped in bacon with roasted garlic, caramelized onions, apricot and cherry glaze with horseradish mashed potatoes.  We were informed by the waitress that there are no changes to any items on their menu which was fine with us. However, I think its ridiculous that they are completely unwilling to compromise in the case of food allergies. As a restaurant, I feel they have an obligation to do that. Anyways, the salad that came before my meal was good thanks to the feta dressing. It was very good dressing and my husband was disappointed when he got his gyro and it didn't have that feta dressing much less any feta for that matter. Feta is a key component of a gyro I always thought. he also said that the yogurt sauce didn't have any flavor.  Correct me if I am wrong but isn't tiziki sauce supposed to be present on gyros? Needless to say, this was not the best gyro the hub had ever had and he informed me that we make better ones at home using roast beef and ranch dressing. Haha. As for my meal, it was ok. But honestly, it tasted like something I have made at home out of the crock pot. I'm sorry but when I go to a restaurant, I expect to be wowed and to have a meal that I don't feel like I could replicate at home. Anyways, I am all about second chances so if someone wanted to go here, I would go but I don't know if it had enough potential for me to go back on my own.

Quite a disappointment. Service was extremely slow and... odd. Food was really overpriced for the quality. I think the ravioli I had was from a freezer pack. This was nothing I couldn't have easily made from home. Overall, an expensive lesson in eating at Romeo's. Won't happen again.

Update: leftovers were inedible due to incredible amounts of oil.

5 stars? How about 6? 6.5?

We had such an amazing experience here. The menu was massive but delicious. The service was fantastic. The deserts were mouthwatering. I can't say enough.

The hubski and I went with a few friends last weekend. Lucas was our waiter and I swear I have never had better service in my life! My friend and I both ordered the spankophillo, which is a cross between spanakopita and pizza. Pictures will be posted shortly. Lucas advised us that the dish is very large and maybe we should split it (at the risk of lowering his tip by lowering the overall bill). We decided to get our own anyway. All meals came with soup or salad. The soup of the day was cream of asparagus, which I ordered. Perfect. The asparagus was obviously grilled before being creamed in the soup, and there was a smoky flavor to it. You could tell that it was made there and not just out of a bag like some places. It was also not microwaved.

My main dish arrived. Lucas was right- it was ginormous. I stick by my decision to have my own. After my delicious soup, I only ate one small slice of the spankophilla in the restaurant. I would love to tell you that this monstrosity re-heats well, but I didn't get that far. Maybe I'll be a little less impatient next time. What can I say? I am impatient. It tastes better warm than hot. Its also great cold.

Spankofilla? We've been spanked!

My friend had the salad with her meal and she loved the yogurt dressing. He husband ordered the gyros and was told by our waiter that it is "the best sandwich in the country". And it was.
Hubski ordered a tuna melt. If I thought my dish was huge... it came on a big Italian roll with slices of tomato and melted provolone cheese. It was $7. For this size and quality, we would have paid twice that.

For dessert, because I saved room, I had a piece of the "Morning After" cake. It is a white sponge cake soaked in sangria... amazing. Our friends had the tiramisu, which was out of this world.
On top of that, while hubski was drinking coffee, Lucas the magnificent was watching which kind of sugar he was using, so when he refilled the coffee, he brought a whole container of just raw sugar. He checked on us regularly, but was not on top of us. He had plenty of suggestions but was not in our faces, and he was just overall the best waiter I have ever had.

Eight thumbs up. We'll be there again soon.

We had been dining at Romeo's Euro Cafe for 2 years now. Each time we select new dishes and leave with our taste buds atingle. From the appetizers that are unique and the perfect starters to the most wonderful main dishes that one can dream of. We love the service and gladly recommend Romeo's to all.

Delicious! Can't wait to go back! Everyone in our group agreed. Loved the appetizer our waiter suggested. Service was great! And not to mention the dessert case! We ended our meal with chocolate covered cookie dough!
A bit disappointed - wine selection is good however if you are searching for real euro - this isn't the place - staff are very nice however food is better at a great hole in the wall deli......

Again... another 5 stars for Romeo's. I really cannot say much that has not been said before but I will comment that I have been to Romeo's 5 or 6 times and I will be a loyal Romeo's customer for years to come. I positively crave their stuffed mushrooms (Think feta, artichoke hearts, and capers...the most amazing thing ever) and I rarely get beyond their pasta dishes to try anything else (I will have to though after reading of their Gyro's) not to mention that the salads are amazing (how do you make a salad amazing I wonder?). However, I do have to say that those of you that did not try dessert are very very sad people indeed because this is one place where the pain (and you will be in pain after one of their entree's) is well worth it. The cakes are out of this world... Satin Bondage, dangerous dilemma, intoxicated love, rhapsody in blush... I choose no favorites. They are all amazing. If you are in the least bit adventurous you must try one of these... or if your a girl go with a few friends, each get a different one, and share. You will not regret the calories.

I went to Romeo's for the "Taste of Romeo's Euro Cafe Table for 10" on
Thursdays.  This was my first time and I was impressed!  Romeo himself sits with you while you enjoy a sampling of an appetizer, salad, 2 entrees and a dessert.  The wine sampling was also a delight.  All their food is made fresh (they don't own a microwave or heat lamps) and Romeo and his wife are passionate about the food they make.  We had the Spicy Lamb potato ball, antipasto salad, tortellini gianni and sherry cranberry pork and for dessert a variation of baklava.  Everything was amazingly good and I can't wait to go back!

BE ADVISED:  A group of 4 employees where I work and some vendors that took them to The Euro Cafe in dowtown Gilbert were diagnosed with food poisoning just last week.  
A few have been treated at the hospital, while others are home fighting through it.   VERY SERIOUS - the proper authorities were notified and are collecting data of everyone affected for the department of health.

Food was OK. Menu far to large, but the food was still made fresh. Atmosphere bland. Two wine lists, So be careful that u don't miss the good stuff. Calamari was very nicely done. Everything else was just ok.

Depending on what you order, Romeo's fluctuates from 4 to 5 stars and is truly a neighborhood gem!  Was there on a Tuesday evening, very quiet, good for us, bad for them.  Their entrance and parking is in the rear, lots of room.  
The four of us ordered one appetizer and three entrees, which come with soup or salad.  As my yelpers warned me about the dinner salad being small and average we ordered soup of the day,  white bean and pork, which tasted wonderful but was just tepid, not hot.  
Our appetizer as per the menu:  (Mushrooms Meteora:
Baked button mushroom caps filled with feta cheese,
capers, artichoke hearts and dill.)  Very tasty, a bit tart, lots more shredded artichoke than mushrooms. 3 - 3.5 stars.
My wife had for her entree as per the menu: (Salmon De Provance:
Salmon fillet baked in parchment paper with, pea pods, scallions, red peppers, asparagus, onions in a caper tomato clam sauce).  She rated it a 4.5 stars.
Our friends ordered as per the menu:  (Seafood Santorini:
Shrimp, calamari, capers, scallions, red peppers, basil pear tomatoes, kalamata olives with feta cheese finish).  They had been here many times and always order this dish which I assume they would rate it 4.5 -5 stars.
And for me, a dish I shall never forget or even get tired of, whose flavor and goodness took me by surprise, the wonderous  and abundant pork tenderloin, as per the menu: 
(Pork Molise
Grilled pork tenderloin, wrapped in bacon, roasted
garlic,horseradish mashed potatoes, honey caramelized
onions and apricot - dark cherry sauce).  The potatoes were delightfully creamy,  mixed with small potato chunks and a mild garlic/horseradish flavor, accompanied by caramelized onions made with red wine I believe, and a fruity sauce that perfectly complemented this dish.  How can dark red ripe cherries cooked with apricots and some wine be any worse than a 5!  I give this dish a 5++ stars.
It will be very very difficult not to order this dish when I return but their menu I'm sure hold more treasures.  This is truly fine dining.

Excellent food.  Very rich, with is not a complaint, but a fact.  Waitress was clearly new and didn't know the dishes.  She could use a manager to help her. Service and atmosphere is always unique and this place is an asset to Gilbert.  Would recommend you try it.  Guaranteed you won't find something similar on a menu anywhere.

We have been fans of Romeo's Euro Cafe for a very long time. We followed him from when he had his restaurant over by the Fiesta Mall, then they disappeared (or so we thought). We were ecstatic when we found him in Gilbert! 

We keep going back. We take friends there, we go alone, we take family....we share the deliciousness with everyone we love. 

I've had pretty much every chicken or  shrimp dish he makes. Also, the eggplant dishes are to die for! Edice's Feta Shrimp, Andalusian Chicken, the house salad with feta dressing!!! Uh oh. I'll have to go back now! The Sunflower Beef is just amazing...
I really haven't found a dish I haven't liked. 

Did I mention, you need to save room for dessert, too!! Ahhhhhhhh, heavenly!
Six stars if i could! Food is so so amazing and flavorful! Been here with friends many times and the servers were super attentive, fun, and welcoming.

The first time I was ever here was with my book club. It is a little small for a group our size but that's my only complaint. I have been there a few times since then and always received good service and great food.  The desserts are AMAZING! This is one of my go to spots in Gilbert for a solo lunch or dinner.  I would give it 5 starts but I was reminded that just because I thought my waitress was really hot that didn't mean they get an extra star ; )

I almost want to give this place less than 5 stars just to be different. But I really can't. 

Its strength lies in (1) its massive number of menu selections, and (2) the undeniably high quality of the food. 

I'd honestly have to give its ambiance no more than 3 stars, because it's nothing out of the ordinary. And its location in Gilbert isn't a big hit with me, though the friend I dined with who lives 2 minutes away would beg to differ. But there's no question: the great food and menu selections here overwhelm all other factors to earn my 5. Gilbertians, be proud.
Expensive, long wait & just ok food.

Delicious
Pork Molise
Grilled pork tender loin, wrapped in bacon, roasted garlic, horseradish mashed potatoes, honey caramelized onions and apricot - dark cherry sauce.

We were out and about trying a new place and were not expecting much. This place is amazing. Quaint and cozy, has a nice bistro vibe. Waiter was one of the best. He was extremely knowledgeable and helpful. Talkative but not intrusive. Now the food..... once we finally decided on 2 out of a million options we were not disappointed! We had the pastrami cream pita and ravioli salad and both were absolutely amazing!  We ended with the German chocolate brownie because you can not leave without grabbing something from the dessert bar! It was heavenly. We can't wait to come back with the moms!

This is one of my favorite places! 

The portions are HUGE and, as you can see from the images posted, the menu is too! Pretty much everything has a Mediterranean ingredient of some sort: shrimp, eggplant, artichoke, lamb, feta, garlic, tomatoes, olives... what's not to love!?

Personally, I stick with appetizers: the Spicy Lamb Potatoes, which I like to call "lamb balls" because it makes me giggle... these large egg shaped croquettes of potato, gyros meat, herbs and spices are served with yogurt sauce. They are so big, I usually wind up bringing 2 or 3 home! PLUS, I have a plan: I have to save room for dessert because the baklava cheesecake is fricking AWESOME!!! (so is the caramel cheesecake) 

I still want to try the wine pairing dinners. They're held monthly on a Monday and at $45, seem to be a steal! Looks like they pick a label and build a four course meal around it! Check out some of the past menus: http://www.eurocafe.com/calendar.html

My wife and I tried the Euro Cafe this weekend. Place is small and quaint with a huge dessert display case in the entrance and looks amazing! We were greeted by friendly hostess and servers and were excited to give it a try.

Received our menus. All I can say is WOW -- overwhelming. Although many items seemed to share similar ingredients, it's extremely difficult to do that large of a menu well -- especially in such a small restaurant. 

We got even more nervous when we saw one of the staff walk right through the dining area with a large bag of frozen stuffed pasta to the kitchen. This happened again later with something else, but I couldn't see what was in the bag. Not sure if they are making trips to the grocery store or they have a walk-in in a different area of the building, but it wasn't very professional and was an indicator of what was to come. 

Anyways, the food. Well it looked nice and was a large portion but it went downhill from there. Both entrees seemed like a confusing jumble of flavors and textures overwhelmed by the different marinated/flavored ingredients that made up the dishes. In both cases, the protein (shrimp, chicken) tasted like they were boiled or poached and had little flavor. 

Anyways, maybe we just ordered the wrong things. But to be honest I won't take the chance again to find the better ones. Maybe the chef/owner needs to reduce his menu by 50-75% and concentrate on what works well. Its pretty hard to do 100 menu items (my estimate) without compromising.

I come here often. This was actually my third time this week. I brought my daughter who wanted to order the feta pasta salad but was afraid she wasn't going to like the mustard vinigarette. She hates mustard. I assured her she would like it but she insisted on asking for a different kind of dressing and the server told her no. So i asked if he could bring out a teaspoon of the mustard vinigarette so she could taste it. The server told me he would have to ring it in and i would be charged for a side of vinigarette. I told him no and told him we will need a few minutes to decide if we even wanted to stay here or go somewhere else to eat. He comes back and asks if we are staying. I was surprised that he didn't seem to care less. I asked again if he was sure she couldn't try just a small taste because I love it and I'm sure my daughter will, too. He said he will ask but his name is not Romeo and doesn't own the restaurant. Wow, that was rude. He comes back with a tiny amount and she likes it. 

A few minutes later a grouchy old man comes out from the kitchen and made some kind of loud scene about spending only $30 and stomps out of the restaurant. I never would've noticed him if he didnt have that little temper tantrum. I was spending $30 so it may have been referring to me. Then I notice the servers going outside. So I looked up info about this place. Sure enough, the man that made the scene is none other than Romeo himself. 

It's too bad, I dined there often and I fly 150-300 people a day into this city and recommended this place to people frequently since its hidden from all the other restaurants in downtown Gilbert. Well, I can guarantee you that will never happen again. 

Sorry Euro Cafe, don't bite the hands that feed you.

Nope. Nope. Just, nope.

I wanted to like this place. The menu looked good (even though it is waaaaayyyy too big). Our server was pleasant enough and made wine suggestions. And they put cucumber in the water, which is awesome because I love cucumber in my water. So this is where the two stars came from.

The food, however, is terrible. We started with the Eggplant Cappicola. It came out 22 minutes after we ordered it and I was flummoxed as to what I was supposed to do with these things. They really didn't have any flavor at all and my husband said his portion was cold in the middle. I ate about two bites of mine. 

I ordered the Shrimp Giouvetsi on Fillo. When the waiter set this mess in front of me, I was a little appalled. The fillo dough was a soggy mess on the bottom and the edges were ridiculously thick. The shrimp/tomato/artichoke concoction in the center of it tasted weird. Too much rosemary. Like, tree branches of rosemary. It was not OK.

My husband ordered the Chicken Astoria. I tried a couple of the baby corns and the sauce wasn't bad but, like mine, the presentation was awful. Now, don't get me wrong, if food tastes good, you could bring it to me in any presentation and I wouldn't scoff but none of this tasted GOOD. Some of it was OK but none of it was GOOD. Scratch that, the side salad was good. So, there's that.

I won't be come back here. $58 for a terrible appetizer, 2 sub-par entrees, and one glass of wine (I drank water) is not worth the money. And it took 90 minutes to get through this horrid meal. Not OK.

I now see my daughter and I are not the only ones to receive bad service here.  So sad since this place had the potential of being a real find. My daughter and I went here on a girls day out. We were at first excited to see the display case full of beautiful looking desserts. I had creme brulee. It was pretty good. My daughter ordered this chocolate shell tart with what was described as a white chocolate filling. It did not taste like white chocolate at all and it actually had the texture of Crisco shortening. Yes shortening!! Not at all what you want in a dessert.My daughter took one bite and put it down. I tasted it to see if it really was as bad as she said and I had to agree. No problem. I told my daughter "I am sure when the server comes back they will let you exchange it". When the server came back  she only said "Oh I am sorry you did not like it " and took it away. She came back with the bill with both desserts on it. She never asked us if we would like to exchange for something else. When I looked at the bill I said my daughter did not like her dessert could she have something else? She said she would have to "add it to my tickett". I told her it was not polite for her to ask us to pay for a dessert that clearly she only took one bite of because it was not good. She said it was policy to not take things off the bill just because someon did not like it. So...just like other reviews here I will not be back. If the customer does not like it. They don't like it. If they think you are rude and have terrible manners they won't be back.Your service always has to be as good as your food! If you don't even have good service you have nothing! You lose!
Not a new concept.

Very extensive menu with large selection of wines. Enjoyed gyro feta dill fritters on appetizers. Not very kid friendly...chicken and vegetable plate came with raw carrots, cucumbers, onions, peppercini, and then bell peppers (kids?). Gyro had authentic sliced meat and great pita. Offers a menu sampler deal on Thursdays to explore 2 entrees and 5 wines for $30. Probably a good option.
Excellent service and wine selection.  The menu is expansive, diverse and original.  It definitely has a European flare. And yes, the food is awesome.!.!

This place doesn't look like much, but the food is wonderful.  I've gone a few times with a women's group of 6-10.  Every single one of us enjoyed our lunch.  The menu is extensive, so takes a few minutes to get through, and then a few more to decide among several tasty-sounding items. 

Last time I ordered the Chicken Tropical pita sandwich.  This had a large piece of chicken topped with Canadian bacon, wrapped up with Swiss cheese and a pineapple slice and coated with a honey dijon dressing.  Yum!  Others ordered the Reuben (also a pita sandwich), Monte Karlo, and a Vegetarian that included artichoke hearts and hearts of palm.   One friend ordered the Antipasto Salad, and the beautiful presentation of it made everyone smile. 

In addition to delicious entrees, the Euro Cafe has a display case of European desserts.  We were all too full to have dessert with lunch . . . but that's why they have to go boxes.

In all fairness, this review reflects their desserts, because that is all that my friend and I ordered while we were here. We had already eaten lunch and just wanted something sweet. I'm pretty sure I had dined here in the past, but I honestly cannot remember what I ordered or what my impression was, so I'm basing it on my most recent experience of the desserts. 

The two of us ordered a strudel, a baklava, and an apricot thing. The strudel was probably our favorite. It was flaky and the filling (not exactly sure what the filing was composed of) was really good. The apricot thing was weird. I don't recommend it unless you really like dried fruit; my friend described it as "fruit leather". Lastly, the baklava. We were really excited about the baklava. It was huge. There were so many layers, and the layers were really thick. Well, clearly, we don't know a thing about baklava, because the thick layers should have tipped us off that this would not be a good baklava. There were just sooooo many nuts. It got to be quite overwhelming. The nuts were rather soggy instead of crunchy, and just really took away from enjoying a baklava. So, even though the desserts might look good in the display, they don't always taste so good.

Service was also weird. It wasn't good or bad, just weird. It felt like they were doing things that didn't make sense, but we got our food, our utensils, and our waters, so I guess it was okay.

Last thing: the cucumber in the water wasn't fresh. I really wish they just wouldn't do that.

**********This review is for the gluten free desserts only. ***********

First I'd like to say that I appreciate their awareness of gf, and offer desserts that are labeled as such.  
I bought the white chocolate truffle "tart" that has a dark chocolate shell.  Looked absolutely delicious.  My friend took the first bite and made a face.  I tried it, and it tasted like it had been in the freezer for too long, or maybe behind the glass for too many days.  We agreed that it tasted like freezer burn.  I thought it was a shame to go up and ask for my money back.  But I couldn't eat it, and it was $5.75.  The gal said she couldn't give me my money back because I had taken a bite out of it.  So, I got the creme brulee.  She torched the top of it and gave it a nice crispy shell.  Again, looked delicious.  My friend and I both took a spoon full of it, and immediately looked at each other, like - oh my gosh, yuck!  It was so sweet, we could hardly finish eating it.  Terrible.  Now, I have quite a sweet tooth. I can eat sweet and rich desserts when others can't.  So, for me to say that a dessert is too sweet, that is something.  There was no way I was going to take it back up to the gal because it seemed controversial to take the first one back.

Stopped in to place a take out order at 6 PM during the week and there were 2 other tables with guests eating food.  I placed one to-go order. I watched people come in be seated, place their order, and to my surprise and dismay, the groups of people that came even 10 minutes AFTER I placed my order got their food first. Its not that my order was a complicated dish. I flagged down the waitress that took my order and told her I had been waiting for 40 minutes and why was one take-out order taking so long? she shrugged her shoulders and said, "Its always like this." I told her I wanted to talk to the manager, and she said there wasn't one there. I asked her to check on my order, and she did and said, its almost done (it wasn't).  It took one hour and seven minutes until I got dinner!!!  I left a message for the manager to call, and I did not get a return call.  I stopped by to talk to the manager, and was told they were in a meeting. I gave it one last try and stopped by, and the manager sent the message that he was busy in the kitchen. I asked the waitress how long would he be?  She asked him and came back with the message, "When I am done."  How unfortunate that the manager does not care about customer service. I'd rather go to a restaurant with leadership that cares.

Been here four times and really enjoy the variety on the menu. This is a small restaurant (charming) with a kitchen that amazes me. I do not know how they prepare such a wide range of food in the space. I've enjoyed appetizers, gyros, and their pork molise. We found everything to be tasty and served with a nice presentation. Always found the waitstaff to be knowledgeable and helpful. Just a great spot for an enjoyable taste before going to our favourite theater, the Hale. Plenty of parking around back.

Ooo, I felt so *cool* just stepping through the door of Romeo's Euro Cafe. Romeo's serves an impressive variety of drinks and foods from all over Europe and America, with emphasis on the Mediterranean region. All in a quaint yet trendy atmosphere. 

The Undici Undici Fine Art Coffeehouse is located adjacent to the Euro Caf and offers more than 20 different types of coffees, as well as Euro's fine dessert menu. They also feature live local music and have a gift shop. See how cool this place is?

Try the Undici Sunrise with freshly squeezed orange juice, ice cream, vanilla syrup and whipped cream, or the Intoxicated Love cake, pairing white, milk, and dark chocolates with Grand Marnier, Kahlua and Jack Daniels. Some of the "real" food choices are just OK, but the desserts and specialty drinks are to die for!

Been wanting to try this place and finally did. The interior is great! Cool mellow setting. 

We only got take out so can't speak for service.

The food was amazing! The menu is huge too! We got the Roasted Almond Tortellini dish. SO FREAKING GOOD! Sauce is creamy and rich and perfecto.

Our friends got a similar tortellini dish and also looked amazing. 

Very creative dishes and lots of variety. 

Definitely going back!!

This place is wonderful and I hate to see when someone says something negative.  People should read the menu before ordering.  The menu clearly states NO CHANGES WILL BE MADE  (If this does not suit you then get up and leave) Too bad people cannot understand PLAIN ENGLISH. 

YOU 'ROCK' ROMEO!!

This has become a favorite after only a few visits. Fortunately I have had the opportunity to see many dishes with "tablemates," and much of what I have seen and eaten is extraordinary. The menu is large with lots of choices to confuse. So far, I haven't seen anyone disappointed.

The only thing keeping it from being Five Stars for me is that the service can and often is a little slow, with various excuses given. Additionally, on a couple of occasions I have felt cramped in by the other tables being so close. 

The food, in both preparation and appearance here is FIRST RATE and while their extensive menu is too big to have sampled even a small percentage of it, somehow I feel it wouldn't be there (on the menu) if it wasn't going to be terrific.

A great little "find," that has already been found by many.

I would say I'm in love with their menu but the service...while good..was painfully slow and the restaurant wasn't that busy..I guess on his defense he was the only server on a Sunday afternoon.  They kind of have late hours on the weekends for earlybirds like us.  Will comeback for the soup and gyro platter...desserts were also excellent!

Thanks to some fabulous Yelp reviews, M and I decided to eat here last night.  I had some idea about how massive the menu is, but had no idea it was like a book!  We intended on going there for a salad, but were enticed by other food.  

The parking lot near the building offers plenty of spots.  You enter through the little gift shop area where you get a preview of the dessert counter.  

We ordered the Mushroom Meteora which is mushrooms stuffed with artichoke, capers and feta cheese.  OMG!  So good.  I enjoyed a staff suggested glass of Pinot Grigio, M had their passion fruit iced tea.  I also ordered the Whoo-Ahh iced drink which is kind of like Starbuck's Caramel Macchiato.  It was soooo good!  Caramel, chocolate, espresso, oh my!  They do serve beer and lots of wine options.

For dinner I had the Mostacciolli Secundo which was sauteed onion, artichoke and penne pasta in a creamy ricotta sauce covered in mozzarella.  M had the gyro plate that came with a HUGE portion of gyro meat that was absolutely delish!  

For dessert M had a blended ice drink of chocolate and mint.  I had the chocolate covered cookie dough and regular coffee.  The only reason we had room for dessert is because we stopped eating our entree.  Figured we have it for lunch in the next couple days.  

Warning!  The portion sizes are HUGE!  I didn't listen to the reviews and ended up with so much extra food!  So be prepared!  But DO save room for dessert!  There is TONS of chocolate!  Also, make sure you have plenty of time as the service is slow, but it really lets you enjoy each part of your meal.

We have been going to Euro Cafe for years (old Mesa location too back in the day) for special occasions as well as regular dining.  The food is 5 stars but I am giving it 2 stars after today's service for a special occasion.  Euro Cafe needs to step it up with their wait staff.  

The restaurant was not busy on a Sunday night and the waiter took a while to come over and greet us.  However, there was no hello or greeting when he came over to give us our waters.  He barely spoke or had a personality.  We were there for my mom's bday dinner and ordered a bottle of wine, main courses and dessert.  The waiter never even said Happy Birthday after we told him it was my mom's bday and she was even opening presents (Bday celebration was pretty obvious).  Very disappointed in the effort the waiter did not put forth for a special occasion and barely spoke to us when he waited on us.  

This place is not cheap by any means and I would expect higher quality service for this establishment.

I love this little gem in the heart of Gilbert. Just as a small heads up, if you do not like feta or capers this may want to be a place you avoid because they are on 80% of the food and they do not so substitutions. I ordered one of the shrimp dishes and it was awesome however they didn't clean the artichokes perfectly and I got a few chokes in the middle. The whole party I went with had awesome meals and the feta salad dressing is amazing!!! I am not a huge fan of dressing and I loved it. Most definitely will be back!

I've been going here since it was in Mesa accross from MCC. I haven't been here is about a year, so I'm not sure if ownership has changed, but the food was not good. Probably last time I will eat there. Sauce was bland and watery and just not good. Seemed like they skimped on the ingredients.

The wait was very long for table and it got worse from there. We sat down and it took awhile to be greeted. Once we ordered the food took FOREVER. I have never waited that long for food and the food was boring. It was flavorless and I felt like I could've made a better meal at home. the restaurant was hot and I left greasy and smelling like the back kitchen. This was my first experience here and definitely my last!

One of my favorite restaurants in the valley! I'm vegetarian and I've never had a dish there I didn't like. They have a huge menu and a great wine selection. (The only reason I didn't give it 5 stars is because the seating area is somewhat small and they don't do anything special for birthdays.)

Love this place for times when you are looking for something different than the sea of chain restaurants we have out here. If you get a chance, I recommend the chefs tasting. It's a lot of fun to do with friends, you get to chat with a very interesting guy, you will probably sample some dishes that you might not ordinarily try, and if you pair it with wine, watch out. The wines were nice choices, and I didn't even realize how easily that wine was going down until I realized I was having difficulty walking upright.

Oh Romeo's Romeo's wherefore art though now in Gilbert?

I have loved this place for many many years.  Their pita sandwiches are fabulous.  The house salad with the creamy feta dressing is wonderful.  I'm always in the mood for one of their fabulous lemon tarts.  I've always had decent service there although on a busy night it takes a while for the food to come.  I'm glad they are doing well in Gilbert, but I miss having them down the street in Mesa.  The new space is cleaner, more cafe like with small tables and large windows.  

Of the entrees that I've had there, I"m partial to Kasseri Chicken, Plaka Chicken, and the Roasted Almond Tortellini.  But hey, find your own favorites, there is  a lot to love at this place.  Portions are pretty big on everything, so come hungry.

First I would like to say that everyone's review on here is so wrong...  This place is expensive and the food is under salted and had no flavor.  The service was by far the worst ive seen in such a small cafe. The waitress, in which remained nameless because she never introduced herself, was rude and presumptuous. Our first impression was trying to walk in a door and her yelling "go to the front " . So we started to search for the front of the building.  When we found it they seated us immediately but then did not come back to the table to take our order for 20 min.  When she arrived she was rushing and honestly acted like she didn't want to be a middle aged women waiting tables in Gilbert on a Friday night (cant blame her for this). However be kind, and respectful to your tables and then your tip will be grand.  We waited another 30min for the food to come out and it was underwhelming to say the least. We  thought well maybe the desert is better so we spent another way 13 dollars on desert. The German chocolate brownie was dry,  flavorless and horrible  and the texture was grainy.   Nonetheless we weren't happy and tipped the minimum.  120 dollar bill crappy service and a couple of baths from her filling up the water cup too aggressively and we were ready to run out of this place. Then the waitress screams out the door 5 dollars on a 120 $bill is unexceptable.  Well your service and food was unexceptable.  If you were nice at all and attentive then you would have had a larger tip.  Best of luck-we won't be back  .

Romeo's Euro Cafe is a small place in downtown Gilbert, on the bottom south floor of what appears to be an old office building. I had never been, and met a friend for lunch who goes as a staple.

The interior was quaint, and the walls lined with wines. I wonder how they can have good wine though, given that it was so very hot in there? The menu was vast, and had all types of European fare, from Greek to Italian, seafood to vegetarian.

We opted to split the Asparagus puffs, which were heavenly goodness wrapped in filo. I had an iced chai, which I found to be underwhelming. The waiter was fantastic, always making sure that our beverage glasses were full, and timed our meal appropriately. 

The house salad dressing is great. My pal even took a bottle home. I ordered the manicotti marinara for my entrée. The dish was molten, as to be expected. The ricotta filling was uber cheesy, and the sauce not too acidic. I enjoyed it. But, for $15 for the two small filled pasta shells, it seemed a bit pricey. But who can put a price on good food, really?

After our meal, we both hit the bakery. I got 2 chocolate covered cookie dough balls, 2 apricot finger thingies, and a chocolate truffle bar. All were amazing!

I would eat here again. I'll bet it looks great in here at night.

The service here is terrible!! I asked for my dressing on the side and they refused to comply they said they must put the dressing on. I was appalled. I then proceeded to wait nearly an hour for a Greek salad with NO meat. When I asked about the wait time I was told this is an average amount of time and I need to be patient. When my food did come out it was not the correct order. There was no apology. Just a heads up a Greek salad does not come with lettuce.

My fiance and i decided to have our wedding reception at Romeo's Cafe....Great Choice!!
Melodie was a pleasure to work with and her advice regarding our food choices proved to be right on point.
The evening went perfectly and our guests loved all of the food. The party room is situated in a cool area with seating outside as well as inside.
We made the perfect choice for a small reception of 18 people. Highly recommended

Shortly before Christmas, my partner and I decided to get away from the crowds at the north end of Gilbert Rd. and dine at Romeos Euro Cafe. There was no wait, and we immediately seated at a cozy table near the window. The ambiance in the restaurant is quaint, and the decor is inviting. The server was prompt and attentive. 

My partner order a dish that came with mashed potatoes. When he asked for butter, the server told him there would be a charge of 50 cents for butter. At first, we thought he was joking.  Once we realized he was serious, we asked to speak to the manager about the butter charge, and she confirmed that we would have to pay 50 cents for butter to apply on the mashed potatoes or bread that came with the meal.  When we pointed out that our meals came up to $64, and they would be losing 2 customers over 50 cents, she was not concerned, and maintained that they needed to charge the fee for butter. I ordered a pasta and shrimp dish, which was bland. 

I stopped going to Euro Cafe when it was on Longmore, in Mesa, because of the chef's refusal to modify dishes by omitting cheese, and now I will no longer go to this restaurant because of a ridiculous charge for butter.  If you go, BYOB- bring your own butter.

I have driven by here multiple times and always wanted to stop in. We finally had the bright idea to come in and check it out.

The menu is HUGE. I mean HUGE. It took me about 20 minutes to go through it (much to the chagrin of our server, I'm sure). If you are panning to come in, take a look at the menu prior to coming in to narrow down your choices prior to taking a seat, trust me.

The service was great, the atmosphere is very cool and it definitely has a euro vibe to it. The menu is a little on the pricey side for what's being offered.

There had a few good veggie options...but to me meatless is not always healthy. Most everything here is covered in cheese or sauce or is deep fried, which quite literally stresses me out because I don't prefer those options. Yes, I know I'm being a bit dramatic. :)

I ended up with stuffed peppers. It has brown rice and veggies covered in cheese and baked. Decent. But holy cheese!

I may stop in and give it another shot in the future, but for now it's checked off of my list.

The good: They have a large menu with tempting descriptions.

The bad: if you go on a group prepare to wait, and wait, and wait.

The ugly: we found a maggot on one of the dishes, another got his order all mixed up.

I don't mind that much anymore if a place ENFORCES a group tip, but at least be CONSCIOUS that your working team DOES deserve the tip. For the service and the LOOONG wait we had, it doesn't make much sense to leave more tip.

We've been frequenting Romeo's Euro Cafe for some time now and tonight we celebrated Valentine's Day with a feast fit for kings and queens. The ambiance is lovely, with a definitely European feel to it, lighting is subtle and romantic and the menu is chock full of wonderful creations inspired by various European countries. From Paella to Transylvanian style chicken and especially the Marco Polo ravioli, every item is meant to please your palate. Portions are just perfectly sized and the wine selection is well above average. Service was pleasant and courteous and if you're lucky you might even run into Romeo, the owner and master chef extraordinaire. Oh, so I don't forget, the dessert assortment is out of this world. Great job, Romeo!

This medium size restaurant with a display of baked goods as you walk in is a gem in the Gilbert Food District.  We arrive at the right time and was seated immediately.  We order their Feta Dill Fritters, Mediterranean Stuff Gyro and Ravioli Calavo.  Everything was season so well and flavorful.  Cooked to perfection, the meat was so moist and melted in your mouth.  The Feta House dressing and yogurt sauce is delicious too.  Our server Patrick was very helpful and kind enough to point us to 2 of the dishes we ordered.  I'm already anticipating my next visit here, can't wait to come back for more.

I had the most amazing food at Romeo's Euro Cafe tonight. I wish I could tell you what I ordered but the owner was creating a new menu for his specials every other Tuesday for $33.00 and had brought me a dish. The ribs were falling off the bone.  The mustard potato salad had so much flavor and the consistency was perfect.  The large bean salad with marinara sauce was delicious.  A picture is worth a thousand words so check it out.  I would highly recommend this to all my family and friends.  You could pick anything randomly off the menu and you will love it.

We returned to Euro cafe, over a year after the kitchen smoke filled experience.  As we walked up my wife said that if it was smokey again we would just leave. Luckily the kitchen vent was working correctly and we enjoyed our favorite dishes.  The waiter was excellent as well.  Happy to be back to an old favorite.  The Feta Gyro is a must try.

My wife and I stopped here on a Saturday afternoon. Food was fantastic, service great.  I even learned a few things, like feta dressing is a lot better than feta cheese and gyros meat is a lot more than just something carved off a cone ;the gyros were fantastic.
Definitely coming back. Everything was fresh and delicious.

Went here last night on a friend's recommendation...so glad we did.  The food was absolutely delicious! Since we like to do "Meatless Mondays", this was the perfect place.  There were  quite a bit of options and we both went with the Vegetarian Pita...so delicious! And how can you go wrong when you're surrounded by wine?! The only reason I didn't give them five stars is because the service was rather slow, but we'll definitely be back.
Nice place. They lemon tart was very good but the white chocolate tart my wife ordered was old and not good. Our meal was good but the service was slow.

While the meal I had was authentic and fresh (more onions than I'd like), I had to settle for the menu item because there are NO SUBSTITUTIONS. I am a diner who believes I should get exactly what I want when ordering at a restaurant because I'm using my hard earned money to pay for it. Romeos believes his dishes are created to absolute perfection and any deviation from this would ruin the taste of the dish. That is fine, but I didn't find perfection with the menu so I will probably not return for a meal. However, the desserts are delectable. Amazing selection. If I return it will be for dessert only.

This is a great little cafe tucked into a corner of downtown Gilbert. The menu is... eclectic, and even overwhelmingly large. However, everything I have had here has been delicious, and I have heard nothing but good from friends about this place as well. I can't wait to try something from their desert case, I haven't made it that far yet though since their portions can be quite generous. They have a good wine selection, and the bloody mary I had here was not bad either. Also their creamy house feta dressing is quite delicious as well. We often drive by this place and say "man we need to eat there again" on our way to some of the trendier Gilbert spots, but I really do need to get in here more often. There are so many more things on that massive menu that I want to try.

Lets just say that I don't eat here often enough. Its small, its boutique-y, but damn is it good. 

I've had several menu items over the last couple of years I've stuffed my face here, literally, if its something you like and its on the menu, it will be good. If its something you are unsure of and its on the menu, chances are it will be good. If you like Mediterranean/Greek food even a little bit, you will love this place. The deserts are crafted well while also being plentiful, and the wine defines this place as legit.

I am conflicted about this place. Its not particularly close to where I live, and they don't do reservations, its small, and you sometimes have to wait a while if its a busy night. However, in order to manage their quality and manage their costs, I see why they would benefit from having a small restaurant, and in some regard it adds to the exclusivity of its existence.

Alright, enough with that bullshit, just go there and enjoy an awesome meal.
Very delicious baked goods and coffee! Tons of menu items to choose from! Went for dinner with my family ( 9 of us) and everyone really liked what they got!!

As it turns out, India Palace is closed on Sundays and as a result, we googled another alternative dining venue that would provide a good Yelping opportunity...Hence this review...

Full marks MUST be given to this place since the ambiance, the service, the fare, and the wine were not in any way lacking.  With a focus on dishes named for Greek cities but presented to the rest of the world, the menu had twists on classic Mediterranean favorites.  Upon arriving, you'll pass a dessert box that may alter your initial intention to have something savoury.  I advise you to simply save room because the additional view of the multitude of worldly wines welcome wavering wanting with wonderous whites and well balanced reds.  Wow.  

I had  dish named Salonika Chicken which featured a beur- blanc with orange liquor sauce....WHAT?  Yum is what.  Creative and charmingly presented, I spent about 3 hours in this place remembering how to pass a Sunday afternoon with great conversation, super delicious food, and the best of company.  Don't we rush enough in this life?  I value that there was not a hint of hurry here while our server was attentive and happy and helpful.  Others in the restaurant were also very happy and huddled in conversation that was muted by some low playing music with a non Euro theme.  If this place piped in the music of Italy, France, and Germany...I think we would truly have to add another star!  I really LOVE it here and this will be my new hide-out...
Ooooopsss!  now I've told all of you!  Oh well.  Something so good should be Yelped.  I think the placwe is charming mostly and just the excuse I needed to Euro-pose...and you know that I did!

Stopped in on a whim ... so glad we did!!! Food was amazing!!! Melodie was hilarious and took time to visit with us during our attempt to eat way more dessert than anyone should!!! Definitely recommend the gyro, the cheesecake brownie and the mushroom appetizer!!!
I work nearby and this is a go to for delicious, consistent food that never disappoints.  The menu is absolutely humungous so you're sure to find something for everyone.

We were visiting Art Intersection on the second floor and the desert case lured us in. Let me say: it did not disappoint!

It was very quaint inside; very moody lighting and beautiful brick walls. Something homey and authentic that a lot of hipster wine-and-dine places try to achieve in Gilbert but don't quite get there.

I have been here twice now and both times were such a great experience.

In the first visit, I got the pastrami cream pita, which was EXCELLENT. I went out of my comfort zone when ordering it and was very pleasantly surprised by the layers of flavor. My only complaint was a bit too much thousand island dressing, but that didn't really affect it much. There was so much creamy/savory/saltiness packed into a little folded pita. Plus, it was filling!

The second time around I ordered a linguini with a black pepper encrusted chicken breast and a mushroom marsala sauce. It came with a salad and bread! It was absolutely divine. I enjoyed every bite! I would have paid 18$ to have just a single noodle. The chicken was tender and the pasta was cooked just right.

Also, it is worth mentioning that you should ALWAYS order the house made chips. No matter what. Trust me on this one! They're to die for.

The deserts are something else. I could probably try anything and love it! Our favorites are Romeo's birthday cake and their mocha brownie. Delicious!

Can't wait to come back here again. Take someone here if you want them to feel special!

I had such high hopes for this place, especially after reading all of these great reviews and I was thoroughly disappointed. 

First of all, they request that you do not make any changes to their menu items - which is just nuts to me. I couldn't request that a salad NOT have mushrooms thrown on top for some reason....apparently it's too much trouble? 

Second of all, the one or two things I did find on the menu without mushrooms were salads and one didn't even come with lettuce. So I defaulted to another salad and it came how it came - which was pretty bad. The dressing had no flavor whatsoever, and the salad as a whole was just boring. Iceberg lettuce, red pepper, and artichoke hearts...that's it! 

Now, my coworkers all loved their meals so I may give them another shot, but it's not likely. Any place that doesn't let you modify your order is just not a place I want to go.

My review still isn't a five star.  This is not really a favorite place of my husband's, but he does love the fries and feta sauce.  He is not a sauce person, but with these fries, they are awesome.  

The food this time was much better than the time he and I came with another friend.  The Bacon Subburger looked beautiful and my husband ate the whole thing.  I got one of my normals, which was a feta gyro.  

The restaurant was about 1/3 full, but many tables still opened.  The place was a bit warm and humid, but not terribly uncomfortable.  I was disappointed that the tasty regular water they used to have with the Brita (sp?) filters was not the case anymore.  This is actually the first time I've seen them have the regular water pitchers that other restaurants have, rather than the delicious water they used to have, or have had for over 2 decades.  The water had a not great taste to it.  That was a HUGE disappointment.  This is one of the reasons for the 4 star rating.  

Our server was okay.  He didn't do a bad job, nor a great job.  He was just doing his job.  But, since we don't usually dine in much these days and for the past few years, it's hard for me to say whether this is par for the course now or not.  But, I remember for many years, the servers were so personable and wonderful.  They acted like they really cared about the customers and got to know them, rather than just doing their jobs.

Edice was my very favorite.  Our server did all the things he was supposed to, nothing more, nothing less.  Having well above average service before had me coming more often.  Maybe that's why we haven't come very often either.

It's not enough to have good food.  Because the food remains consistently good, it puts it at a 5 star, even though you cannot change anything to the menu items.  But, that is a standing thing of this restaurant.  However, service and everything else, 3 stars.  Loved the quirkiness of the prior servers that were there for years.  But, maybe that's not what people are doing now.  

We'll be back, but rather take out  more or less.  As others have mentioned, service wasn't super fast, but it wasn't slow either . . . maybe tended a little slower.

This place is what you would call "quaint".  has a boutique feel to it.  Hard to find even though it is located in the hot spot of Gilbert (right across the street from Postinos).  The place is small but the food is good and authentic.  The menu is HUGE and overwhelming.  Its really amazing how big their menu is when their kitchen is not the biggest.  I guess you cant say that they have a particular taste or menu other than European.  The dishes are pretty big and hearty and the prices are decent.  Definitely a good restaurant to goto if you want a change of pace and something different then the box restaurants. And the dessert menu/selection is GINORMOUS! and very delish with a big variety from Chocolate, creme brule, carrot cake, cheese cake and they rival that of fancier bakeries.

Pros
-fresh and authentic food
-big selection of food
-good service and knowledgeable staff
-BIG DESSERT MENU
-they have wine tasting nights (call to find out more)

Cons
-small, deff not a good place for big parties
-overwhelming menu
-dessert menu will DESTROY YOUR DIET PLANS

I went here recently to give it a try! It has always intrigued me. However, I asked to switch out the Focaccia bread for Pita bread with one of their caprese appetizers and the lady gave me a funny look like it was unheard of to make a change. I mentioned that I like soft bread VS. hard bread (just a personal choice) and she said she would ask the chef. They couldn't do it- so I said ok fine I will take whatever it come with. I also noticed on my way out that they charge 50 cents for water cups if you are in the bakery area?  Its illegal to charge for water cups in Arizona! I doubt I would go back..

Walked here after having dinner at Liberty Market, since I couldn't have any of the desserts offered there.  After the friendly and very helpful female host helped to phone the pastry chef to address my food allergies, I placed my order of a slice of "Dangerous Dilemma" and a chocolate-covered walnut strudel and was seated at a two-top next to a window with a view of a parking lot.  I decided to while away the wait on the dessert by looking at the baubles on display by the entrance.  A few moments later, the host notified me that the strudel had cornstarch, so it's a no-no for me, and that  I would not be able to dine inside since I should not have been seated with an "outside drink."  "Would this be a problem?," she asked. I said no, paid for my to-go dessert, and settled on a bench outside the cafe.  While the two forkfuls that I tried of the multi-layered dense cake (cookie crumb bottom layer, dark chocolate fudge cake, white chocolate mousse, another layer of dark chocolate fudge cake, and then topped with raspberry coulis) were delicious, I inadvertently became the meal of ghost mosquitoes (so I had to pack up and leave, yet again).  All because I had a lidded to-go cup of Liberty Market drip house coffee with me.
The $6.54 (tax included) cake slice was tasty (although almost a bit too sweet), and I can't fault someone for following house rules, but I wished my drink could've been overlooked.  (There were only two occupied tables out of 12 to 15 tables.) Heck, I could've ordered a glass of wine, or another cup of coffee, with my dessert had I not been turned away...

This chic local eatery had a variety of delicious food, excellent service, and a quaint atmosphere that will offer everyone a perfect dining experience. This hidden gem is a new found favorite of mine...can't wait to return!

I've been eating here for well over 10 years. Sometimes once a month and other times every 3 or so months. I have never had a bad meal here. Not even close to average. I've never left without being completely satisfied. I've only had about 1/5th of the items on the menu. All of them are great. Some of my favorites are the Calamari, Chef Salad, Coconut Fried Shrimp, Feta Dill Fritters (are a meal in themselves), Spanaki Balls and Gyros Platter. My 2 top favorites are the Pasta Rustica (love the sausage and shrimp) and the Penna Carbonara ( ask for extra bacon) Oh so yummy.
     I always take about half of what I order home. You really get your moneys worth here. No little dollop of this or squirt of that on your plate. You get a real "cooked from scratch" meal made less than 20 feet away. Like any good place, you will wait for that fresh food and it's totally worth it. Enjoy a glass or bottle of wine from their huge wine selection. If your smart you'll take home something from the desert cases and enjoy it later on. 
     The food is wonderful. Period!

I wish I could give them more stars. The thing is I was really excited about this place and it just didn't deliver. The smell outside? AMAZING The menu? So many options (perhaps too many?) I had so many high hopes...
The trouble is as awesome as some of the menu items sound, if you pay attention you begin to realize that they all are using pretty similar flavors. Meanwhile the food was disproportionately SLOW considering the amount of food we ordered and the amount of customers. It took well over an hour to get a pita, some potato skins, and stuffed mushrooms. I won't even get into detail on how long it took to even get our order in or check at the end. Despite interest in trying a few other dishes we won't be back. As the meme says "Nobody got time for that!"

When we first found Romeo's we were so happy.  Here was a great place to eat, with good European food, great desserts, good prices and a comfortable atmosphere.  Sometimes they even tempt us with alcohol, like once finding Ayinger Celebrator Doppelbock available.  This visit was no exception, though I did not end up with a beer this time.  We had a reservation and were quickly seated.  The water has cucumber in it, which is actually quite nice.  The menu is huge and I know we both try to get something new, but sometimes get a favorite. This day my wife went with a favorite, Athenian Chicken and I tried something new, the Vasco De Gama, an interesting shrimp dish.  We both enjoyed the salad that came as a starter and our mains. With a wonderful dessert case it is hard to resist getting dessert.  There is no dessert menu here, you get up and look at the dessert case to make a choice.  This time we both had cheesecakes, my wife had the Raspberry White Chocolate and I had the Kahlua Frangelico.  Both were excellent, as always.  Service was great and we had another excellent meal.

Wow, we had a wonderful 5 course wine dinner there with Romeo and his lovely wife, Janice, on Thursday evening. Every dish was incredibly delicious, and the wines were spectacular. I have served on our top California wine board for 12 years, and his choices from Sonoma and Napa were all excellent. We plan to return next Thursday evening and bring friends. This is not to miss!

Came in for dessert with my daughter today, after walking around we stumbled upon this place. We enjoyed a slice of the Dangerous Dilemma, and a chocolate covered cookie dough ball. Dangerous Dilemma was rich, delicious, and decadent. The cookie dough ball was surprisingly amazing as well! Their desserts are all made in house! I would love to give the rest of their food a try.

We had an outstanding dinner. The house cab was really outstanding, the Pork Molise the best pork I've ever had. The Shellfish Tortellini and Greek Salad awesome. Our waitress Annabelle was adorable and helpful and we loved her! This place never disappoints!

Romeo as usual Fantastic food & outstanding service. Melody WAITED on the 4 of us for my son's Bday dinner. She's as sweet & kind as ever. First time I tried your curry incredible flavors, a delious meal. First time my brothers been in. You have another new customer, he loved what I call Adult Mac N cheese. Son had cranberry pork, his go to FAVORITE. Thx for a very enjoyable evening out. God Bless & Wish u & ur family many more years great success.

A little on the small side as far as table space goes. Friendly staff that are very knowledgeable about the huge menu. Large portion sizes. The food was ok. A little pricey. 2 entrees, 2 waters and one diet coke was $49.00 before the tip. It was just okay, no hurry to go back.

The best lunch and Cafe food in the Euro genre in the Phoenix metro area. Seriously. This place is stellar. Try their basic gyro pita and fall in love. Try their penne carbonara and be transported. Try their Marco Pollo ravioli main dish and be amazed. I've tried all of those plus the Paella (red sauce based, not saffron), Athenian Chicken, and much more. Enjoyed them all.

What's more, the soups and salads are perfect and fresh. (their soups are especially great since they are all one-off creations that always surprise and taste great). And their deserts are rapturous. I go to lots of restaurants in Arizona and your won't find a cafe with a more complete and we'll done Euro menu that wins on literally every dish. 

And everything is a home made, customized and perfectly fresh rendition of each dish. My wife's favorite place. 

And if you're into wine they also have a large cabinet of expertly curated wines.

You won't miss by going here. Honestly.
Excellent restaurant. Great food. Very large portions. Dessert is a real treat. Only complaint is that their bread was stale our last visit. It is usually fantastic. We are regulars.

The food was delicious.
The service was attentive. 
It took almost an hour for our food to be served.  We came on a night when they also served their Prix Menu to a group of at least 10.  Not sure how many but there was a lot of food passing me while I waited for mine.  

Appetizer was a great start:  Spanaki Balls.  They were so good I could just have those with a side of soup.  

 Pork Molise served with small side salad
Bacon wrapped pork loin was yummy with the cherry sauce.  

Ravioli Bolognese served with small side 
salad.  Meat sauce with sausages was flavorable and rich.  

I would've gave this place a 5 stars but I didn't expect the wait to be so long.  

Well have to come back and try other dishes and hope the wait isn't so long.

We decided to try Something new and non-chain, so this hidden gem came up.  Located in downtown Gilbert it's in a charming little retail property.  Tucked away, you might miss it, but the signage is there. 
The menu is massive, with a greek influence but with many other options, so there is something for everyone.  I tried the Gyro pita sandwich and my friend had the Penne Carbonara.  My sandwich was stuffed with yummy gyro meat, and the taste was as I would expect.  Very good!  I tried a bite of my friends carbonara and it was flavor packed.  Both dishes were a good size so you won't leave hungry.  
They do have many options for wine and then some nice deserts in the front case that had us wishing we weren't stuffed.  
It's a small place so not a tone of seating, and the kitchen is practically part of the dinning room, so it might get a little stuffy.  

Service: A
Food: A+
Ambiance: B
Comfort: C (the heat of the kitchen was a bit much.)

Cute little mom and pop place in Gilbert. The food and service was good. 

Drawbacks.... There is this loud humming noise and they didn't have any music playing so all you hear is humming and other peoples conversation. The atmosphere is cute but the humming and the random conversations you pick up takes way from the quaintness of the place.

First off, you walk into this place and it smells like a European cafe should: competing hints of baking bread, roasting coffee, and various cured meats and cheeses. The wife and I each tried pasta dishes, she the Penne Carbonara and I the Roasted Almond Tortellini. The tortellini were perfectly cooked, and the flavors of the stuffing and the sauce were mild enough while still being hearty and satisfying. We tried the Night Before cake for dessert, which was like an incredibly dense cocoa mousse on a macaroon crust. Definitely as good as it sounds! We will certainly be back, but probably just for coffee and dessert because this place is a bit pricey!

We had a poor experience with takeout not once, but twice. We really hoped giving the place a second chance would result in better quality food, but no such luck.

The first time around, my husband ordered a bleu roast pocket sub and accidentally received a garden pocket sub. He said it was good, albeit runny. I ordered the tortellini kalypso and for the price, I was underwhelmed with the heaviness of the sauce and overall lack of flavor that so many Italian restaurants seem to screw up.  The two redeeming qualities were dessert and the spanaki balls.

Round number two: My husband ordered the burgersub and said it's fine but slightly over-cooked. I ordered the artichoke salmon, thinking it would be tough to screw that up, but I was wrong. The salmon appeared to be seasoned with herbs of some kind but completely lacked salt. The remainder of the dish was too acidic with the hearts of palm, artichokes, and capers and nothing to balance it, and the white wine cream sauce lacked flavor (salt). Cut to dessert and I get three bites into my tiramisu before discovering a long, curly, black hair. Gross, gross, gross.

I try to keep an open mind with dining establishments but the disappointment in quality of food here is all encompassing, especially for the price.

The food is amazing. Incredible. Unique. I adore the food, and as another has said, roasted almond tortellini is my favorite.

Atmosphere is cute and what you'd expect from a privately owned restaurant.  -1 for the seats being quite uncomfy. 

Service is usually great. Mind you, I'm not very picky with service. Just bring my food, fill my drinks occasionally and I'm pleased.  This wasn't the case the last time I went. I took my mother-in-law... And I was actually embarrassed by this waitress. She was rude, didn't offer us the entire options "a salad with feta dressing, k?!", and then when my mother in law asked her what desert she would recommend (seriously, make up something If your not sure) she replied with "you know what, I'm busy!". My jaw dropped. She followed this with "I have a table of 12 and I'm the only one here, but everything is good enough."  I have never been treated like waiting on me in a restaurant was an inconvenience. 

Romeo should be upset as I was, because this kind of service put a bad taste to the amazing food.


I left 4 stars because my service in the past had never been so bad, and I am a regular who loves the dishes.

I love Romeo's service and food from the minute we walk in til the bill comes!  The hostess Hallee is super sweet and competent!  The server,  Melody,  was extremely knowledgeable!  The wine list is extensive as is the menu and everything we ate was delicious!  I recommend this restaurant to all my friends!

I wish I could give this place more than 5 start.
My girlfriend and I started with the popcorn calamari. It was cooked perfectly! Light and flaky on the outside, warm and tender in the inside. We both ended up getting the pita. She got the monte Cristo, and I got a chicken and pepper. Both absolutely amazing. Passion fruit tea, perfect. Then to top everyrhing off, peanut butter cheese cake and a lemon tart. Perfect, perfect, and perfect. Small, not a chain, and perfect.

UPDATED REVIEW since June 2015.  After my previous review, Romeo had reached out to apologize.

We stopped by this afternoon after an appointment we had, at about 11:40.  The restaurant was mostly dead; there were maybe 2 other patrons in.  I realize midday isn't exactly a huge draw with all of the other competition, but that's okay.  The first thing I noticed was that the dessert box looked a little empty; every other time I've been there, it's been completely overflowing.

My wife ordered a feta-avocado wrap and I ordered the Gyros Platter.  We've had the gyros platter before so we mostly knew what to expect.  The feta dressing on the side salad was superb as ever; it's one of my favorite things about Romeo's, and has been since the first time we went.  

When the entrees came out, my wife was surprised at hers.  The wrap was solo, no sides, which isn't necessarily bad because the wrap was actually pretty full.  However, she couldn't detect any taste of feta, and barely any turkey; the avocado was really overpowering.  (And that says a lot -- my wife LOVES avocado.  I hate avocado, so I didn't try it).

I shared mine with my 2-year-old son.  One of the first things I noticed was that the ends of the pita were hard, as if they were stale.  The pita was warmed of course, but the crunch wasn't as if it was toasted too much.  Visually they looked fine.  Even my two-year-old complained that it was too hard to each. 

The gyro meat was as good as it has been previously.  Romeo's gyros has a unique flavor profile that I like.  I don't think that they prepare it themselves -- I don't see a spit anywhere in the back -- but it's pretty tasty.  The gyro was nice and thin, and was cooked to a nice crispness.

Now onto our favorite part, the dessert.  We ordered a chocolate-covered cookie dough ball, and a dark chocolate tart.  The cookie dough ball was average; it didn't "wow" us like it has in the past.  And the chocolate tart, well....  I think there are two schools of thought about dark chocolate.  One is that it "not sweet."  The other is that it is "decadent."  I'll own up to being of the latter school of thought; this dessert was from the former.  The most surprising thing about the "dark chocolate tart" was that it had a layer of peanut butter below the chocolate tart itself.  It was tasty, and neither the PB nor the chocolate dominated the flavor -- but the tart cookie bottom was REALLY crunchy and dry -- again, lending us to believe that it was older.

So even the dessert fell short of our expectations.

Service, too, was lackluster.  He came and retreated as soon as he brought water or whatever.  

Overall, it was not worth the price.  I could imagine us trying a dessert to-go sometime, but I don't think we'll be eating in again.  It's really disappointing to me, too.

From watching things like "Restaurant Impossible" and other similar Gordon Ramsay / Robert Irvine shows, I just feel like their menu is too big to do everything well.  Focus on some of the essentials and narrow it down.
